This post made me sad. When someone is chronically suicidal you do not reason with them or tell them they are wrong. Watch some videos about how to listen to someone who‚Äôs suicidal. They just want to feel heard. If you think you can do that for her, then I suggest reading up on this. If you think you can‚Äôt or don‚Äôt want to, that is 100 percent ok!!! If this is the case, tell her you care about her and therefor will call emergency services every time she threatens. Then do it. 

Either way, good luck. She sounds really unwell and I don‚Äôt think the dynamics of the situation right now are healthy for you OR for her. I hope she gets professional help if her ideation is genuine and/or you build up good boundaries so you stop being the target for this kind of manipulation if it isn‚Äôt genuine.

Grey rock Responses and emotionally disengaging is the only way. Mirroring back what she says while validating her feelings is the best way: you don‚Äôt apologize and you don‚Äôt argue and you don‚Äôt try to fix anything. For example, you say ‚Äúif I were you, I‚Äôd be angry too‚Äù or ‚ÄúI understand, you‚Äôre extremely upset and feel (misheard, misunderstood, taken advantage of etc)‚Äù 
Note that it is technically true : if you were her, you‚Äôd feel what she feels by definition ...bc you‚Äôd have her same brain chemistry. Also just stating your own boundaries and acting on them is good, for example ‚ÄúI completely understand how upset you are. I have a difficult time thinking when someone yells at me, so I will have to go for a run/leave for an hour/call back tomorrow if there is yelling. When validating feelings, try to use ‚Äúwe statements ‚Äú (aka ‚ÄúI understand the anger, and we will work through this together‚Äù) and when stating boundaries be careful to stay away from all ‚Äúyou‚Äù statements and stick to I statements and just describing what you need and what you will do.

Also, it‚Äôs ok to just not pick up the phone. You don‚Äôt need to react and everyone isn‚Äôt always privy to your time at any moment they feel they want it. Try just not picking up...not as punishment, but just bc it‚Äôs ok to keep a steady keel and only engage with a person when you feel ready and happy and willing to do so

That‚Äôs a major gift the pwbpd in my life gave me too. They warned me they were really mentally ill multiple times when we began dating but I didn‚Äôt understand. It took me years to really understand. I had a really naive assumption that everyone‚Äôs internal world was roughly similar to mine- which is deeply untrue. I‚Äôm not even talking about just people w bpd but also the many other spectrums of disordered thinking or psychotic symptoms or even the varying levels of empathy or cognitive ability across humanity. I wish I had been taught this in school but somehow we don‚Äôt educate the population about the differences among us- I suppose because we are so busy indoctrinating the youth to teach them that we are all the same. We need to treat everyone with the same respect and personhood rights but people are certainly not all the same. There are sociopaths who cannot be rehabilitated for example. I do wish there was more widespread education policy around mental health and awareness coupled with compassion and anti-stigma training. You can be compassionate and also have healthy boundaries. In fact, it IS compassionate to maintain and clarify ones healthy boundaries. Something I needed therapy to truly teach me ....

I don‚Äôt understand the last bullet point or what it has to do with bpd. Are you saying that she has had many partners and therefore you worry she has an unstable attachment style? This hardly points to a lack in character unless there is lots of cheating and lying and need for constant adoration from multiple sources to go along with it. 

However, the red flags I missed were my ex showing me self harm cuts all over his arms and telling me he was mentally ill. Sooooo I probably am not the best person to give advice about picking up on tiny subtle yellow flags. Your post seemed like slut shaming to me, to be honest, in that last bullet point, which would be a yellow flag for me as a woman when dating *you* to be honest.

She might not be so hurt and ashamed - she might have said that bc she thought it would work to keep you around (and it almost did). She might be with someone new as she may not be able to connect as authentically as you assume, due to her mental health issues. She might have a more mercurial identity than you realize. I somehow doubt she‚Äôs home pining away for the past so I wouldn‚Äôt assume you are doing her any favors by reaching out. I think you should be honest with yourself that your motivations are probably to relieve your own guilt or feelings of awkwardness around how things ended. This is just a hunch, though- I of course don‚Äôt know her or you. Good luck. I‚Äôm sorry you met someone so unstable. Sounds awful!

It‚Äôs paradoxical but I found that not feeling guilty about being this way helped. Forgiving myself and seeing my personality as a real super trait helped me kind of even out. It‚Äôs actually really a sweet thing to be always apologetic. In certain situations, it‚Äôs really a beautiful trait because it makes others feel at ease. For example, our personalities are really great for making other equally sensitive people feel comfortable and safe. The problem is that it can also leave us vulnerable to people who knowingly or even unknowingly take advantage of this due to their own poor boundaries. The key for me was realizing I wasn‚Äôt trying to stop feeling sorry all the time for the sake of others - I was going to do it for my own sake. I don‚Äôt need to feel sorry all the time or have knee jerk people please skills anymore. They were defense mechanisms from an extremely abusive childhood and I can grow and learn new assertive ways to exist in the world now that I am an adult and can keep myself safe and give myself the love I didn‚Äôt get as a child. It‚Äôs a real process, that‚Äôs for sure. I think the first step is learning to love the way we always say ‚Äòsorry!‚Äô and realizing it was our way of keeping our inner child safe. Once we appreciate it and feel grateful for it, we can choose to pick up that tactic only when needed and not all the time.

This was key for me too. Getting myself to therapy and realizing I was the one who needed to change and have boundaries and healthy self esteem. It isn‚Äôt just the pwbpd who would benefit a lot from change. It‚Äôs us too. Even if that change means leaving the relationship or just changing the dynamics of the relationship. It takes one person to change a relationship and the one person we can control or influence is ourselves.

Sometimes the pwbpd goes down these self pity holes too and they‚Äôre super manipulative bc they just suck you in and drain you. If I choose to be here, it‚Äôs for me. Stop taking guilt or responsibility for things that aren‚Äôt yours to take‚Äù

Before therapy, We‚Äôd waste time in these back and forths and I would try to cheer them up by saying how awesome they are and try to build their esteem. Actually, it‚Äôs not my place to do that. Also, the truth is the things the pwbpd in my life felt guilty about were things they Should feel guilty about (and change) but wallowing in guilt and saying things like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm awful for you so I‚Äôm better off dead or on the streets homeless so I‚Äôll just run away ‚Äú of course didn‚Äôt help any of that and was just more drama and misery for me. The key was stepping away from that entire spiral. You tell them that you are an adult and take ownership of your choices, and if they want to have a pity fest then they certainly can but you will step away bc it‚Äôs not healthy for you. Then you walk away from that entire conversation bc their happiness is their responsibility just like yours is yours. You are there to support them but not a therapist for them to dump all their emotional baggage on. Remember that.

Hi, yes there is. I found a free therapy group for family members of pwbpd that met at a local behavioral clinic. It was very helpful. The key is to realize you are not there to fix or change the pwbpd. You‚Äôre there to take ownership of your own happiness and learn to protect your mental and emotional health. For me, this meant cultivating compassion for myself, learning to have healthy boundaries, learning to stop thinking I can cheer others up or make others happy or affect them at all, and also learning some very practical grey rock tricks for crises times. It helped me change a lot and become stronger and calmer and more centered. I highly suggest joining a group like this. It was life changing for me.

Tips for outrageous comments: grey rock and most importantly truly absorbing that you‚Äôre not in it- (that you just happen to be there). For me, reaching this point meant grieving a bit. You have to truly accept the pwbpd has serious brain chemistry problems and might never get better. You have to really accept that they *are* their actions (as we all are) and then do the hard work to figure out why you would let someone‚Äôs delusional verbal tirades affect your emotional peace or sense of self. For me, it meant realizing I had lots of unhealthy coping mechanisms to try to build the self worth that my abusive childhood stole from me. Mine were just as unhealthy as the ones the pwbpd created, really. It‚Äôs unhealthy and irrational to absorb another persons delusional or erratic anger or blame and I had to really figure out why I did this. It meant relearning my entire way of being in the world. It was tough and also meant grieving the loss of the old me. It changed the way I interact with my family and friends and employers. My life is so much better for it. 

The interactions w the pwbpd in my life improved a lot too actually. Since I stopped being as triggered or feeling personally attacked, it cut down on emotional drama. It takes two people to hurt one another but if one person is spewing out negativity and blame and the other isn‚Äôt affected and takes themselves out for ice cream instead, it really alters that interaction. It‚Äôs the first step. Good luck!!

Everyone gave great advice. I also suggest being horrifically amazingly boring in the meanwhile. Practice a long list of grey rock phrases. Be the dullest person you can manage to be and she might just replace you with someone more exciting and leave on her own. Some examples:
- what did you do today? You: Nothing
-how are you? You: Fine
-why are you being such a jerk?  You: I don‚Äôt know. I‚Äôm tired recently
-I hate you!!! You: Ok. Sorry
-it‚Äôs all your fault and you‚Äôre horrible!! You: You‚Äôre right. Sorry. 

My go to grey rock phrase is ‚Äúok‚Äù bc it can be a response to almost anything. Or even, ‚Äúok. That‚Äôs valid‚Äù even if the accusation is insane and evil (in my head, I just changed it to ‚Äúthat‚Äôs valid...to feel if you are straight insane‚Äù but I didn‚Äôt finish the phrase out loud of course! Really, the key is to keep the phrases technically true. 

And it also helps to practice statements in terms of personal boundaries , for example: ‚ÄúI have a hard time thinking when I hear yelling, so I will leave if I hear yelling again‚Äù. Then, you leave if there is yelling. You, under no circumstance, try to help/criticize/change her. You state your boundaries and what your actions will be and then you act, all very calmly and compassionately. 

The trick is to never react w any emotion at all. Actually, it‚Äôs similar to disciplining a toddler. ‚ÄúIf you hit, I will take the toy‚Äù with no emotion or anger. Similar to parenting a 3 yr old, the moment you‚Äôve become sad hurt angry, you‚Äôve shown your weakness and lost the control. 

Good luck. A lawyer consult, as everyone said,  is a great idea.
